item.description:
The old logging town of Livermore, incorporated in 1876 and named for Samuel Livermore, was once a thriving settlement whose population dwindled by the end of WWII when the forests had been denuded.

Just 6 miles west of Bartlett, the school house, post office, and many remnants of dwellings and foundations remain on the bank of the Sawyer River not far from the parking lot.



This hike goes through a splendid hardwood forest with many types of beautiful flora everywhere. After most of the elevation gain is completed to reach Signal Ridge, hikers are rewarded by the sudden spectacular views for a delightful mile of easy ridge walking.

We'll have a short descent into the woods and a short ascent up to the 4700' bald summit with sensational views of 43 4000 footers in NH and scores of mountains in Maine & Vermont. The stunning views from the open summit and tower are contenders for the finest views in all the Whites!

The round trip is 10.0 miles, 3250' of elevation gain, with 7 - 7.5 hours on the trail.

Trailhead: Sawyer River Road about 2.1 miles from US Route 302, elevation about 1400 feet
44.0704°N, 71.3830°W (WGS84)
WMNF fee site


From I-93 exit 35 near Franconia Notch, follow US Route 3 about 11 miles N to the junction of US Route 302 in Twin Mountain, then turn R on US Route 302 and go E about 19 miles through Crawford Notch to the Sawyer River Road. (This is about 10 miles W of NH Route 16 at Glen.) Go up the Sawyer River Road 2.1 miles, the trail starts on the R just before the Whiteface Brook bridge and the parking lot is on the L across the bridge.
item.why: It's June and if you'd like to see some wild orchids, they should be in bloom at this time. This is a great hike, moderately rated and worth the effort.
